I tossed the phone aside. Earned it? Hardly. Across the room, my reflection in the hallway mirror looked pale, shadows bruising my under-eyes. When had I gotten so gaunt?  

---  

By noon, the guilt morphed into something else. Restlessness. I vacuumed. Reorganized the spice rack. Texted Carlos: *”How’s it going?”*  

His reply was instant: *”🔥🔥🔥 Literally. Grill flared up. Marty’s losing it. Miss u, man.”*  

I winced. Miss me? Since when did anyone *miss* me?  

Since always, maybe.  

Carlos covered for me when Dad died. Gina brought me cough drops during flu season. Even Marty, in his own crusty way, had given me a Christmas bonus every year. “Don’t spend it on strippers,” he’d grunted. (I’d bought groceries.)  

They needed me. But I needed this—needed to prove that I could stop, just once, without the world ending.  

---  

I ended up at the park, clutching a gas station coffee, watching kids chase pigeons. The sky was an achingly pure blue, the kind you only notice when you’re not racing somewhere. For the first time in years, I sat still.  

My phone rang. Marty’s name flashed on the screen.  

Panic surged. *He knows. He knows I’m faking. He’s going to fire me—*  

I answered, voice trembling. “Hello?”  

“Jamie.” He sounded exhausted. “You alive?”  

“Uh. Yeah?”  

“Good. Listen, Thompson wedding went to hell. Groom got drunk, tripped into the cake. Bridesmaid puked in the bathroom. Typical Tuesday.” A beat. “But we survived.”  

“Oh. That’s… good.”  

“Yeah. Anyway, get your ass back here tomorrow. And Jamie?”  

“Yeah?”  

“Don’t forget the damn doctor’s note.”  

The call ended. I sank onto a bench, dizzy with relief.  

---  

That night, I dreamt of the restaurant. The sizzle of the grill, the clatter of plates, Marty’s voice barking *”Fire table six!”* But instead of panic, I felt calm. In control.  

When I woke, the sun was rising, pale gold through my blinds. I laced up my shoes, grabbed my apron, and headed out.  

The guilt hadn’t vanished. Neither had the bills, the burnout, the fear of becoming obsolete. But for now, the world hadn’t ended.  

And maybe that was enough.  

---  

**Epilogue**  

The next day, Carlos greeted me with a fist bump. “Look who’s alive! How was your bender?”  

“Slept for 14 hours,” I said.  

“Nice.”  

Marty stomped past, grumbling about a liquor delivery. But he paused, squinting at me. “You look less like death warmed over.”  

“Thanks…?”  

“Whatever. Get to work.”  

As I tied my apron, Gina grinned. “Welcome back.”  

The kitchen hummed—same grease, same chaos, same symphony of curses and laughter. But something felt different. Lighter.  

I’d taken a sick day. The world kept spinning.  

Maybe, just maybe, I could do it again someday.

samples.prompt: You have always felt like your body doesn't belong to you, one day you wake up and can't control your body as it starts walking towards a pen and some paper and then starts writing.
samples.output:
**Title: The Unseen Author**  

You’ve always felt like a tenant in your own skin. Since childhood, there’s been a dissonance—a quiet, persistent sense that your hands aren’t yours to command, that your legs move with a rhythm borrowed from someone else’s heartbeat. Doctors called it depersonalization; friends joked about you being “spacey.” But you knew it was deeper. A primal wrongness, like a puzzle piece snapped into the wrong spot.  

Then comes the morning it all fractures.  

You wake to the sensation of your spine arching off the bed, muscles taut as wires. Panic surges—your lungs heave, but you aren’t the one breathing. Your eyelids flutter open, and you stare at the ceiling, trapped in a body that has become a machine. It sits up. Swings its legs over the edge of the mattress. Stands. You scream, but no sound comes. Your vocal cords hum with a foreign vibration, a low, animal noise that isn’t yours.  

*This isn’t happening.* You repeat it like a mantra, but your body strides toward the desk in the corner of your studio apartment. The one cluttered with unpaid bills and half-finished sketches. Your right hand—*your* hand, except it’s not—grabs a pen. The left slaps a sheet of notebook paper onto the wood. Your fingers tighten around the pen, knuckles bleaching white.  

Then the writing begins.  

---  

The first stroke is a jagged line, ink tearing through the page. You try to wrench back control, to crumple the paper or snap the pen, but your limbs are stone. The script that emerges is angular, frenetic, nothing like your own loopy cursive. Letters pile atop one another: *THEY KNOW.*  

“Who?” you want to shout. “Know *what*?” But your jaw stays clenched. The pen moves faster.  

*YOU AREN’T SAFE. YOU WEREN’T SUPPOSED TO REMEMBER.*  

A coldness seeps into your chest. *Remember what?* You rifle through memories—birthdays, school days, the mundane blur of adulthood—but nothing surfaces. The pen drags downward, carving a new sentence: *THE HOUSE BY THE MARSH. THE DOOR UNDER THE STAIRS.*  

Your breath hitches. There’s a flicker—a scent of damp soil, the sound of hinges whining. A door. Small, warped, tucked beneath the staircase of your childhood home. You’d forgotten. No, someone *made* you forget.  

The pen stabs the paper again. *YOU WERE CHOSEN. THEY TOOK THE OTHERS. YOU ESCAPED.*  

“The others?” Your mind races. You were an only child. Weren’t you? But now there’s a face—a boy with your eyes, grinning as he thrusts a toy boat into a murky creek. A sister whose name dissolves before you can grasp it. The memories feel grafted onto your brain, fresh and raw.  

Your body hunches closer to the desk, the pen now sketching a crude map: a winding road, a cluster of trees, a square labeled *MARSH HOUSE*. Beneath it, scrawled in frantic caps: *BEFORE THE MOON TURNS.*  

Moon. The date flashes in your mind—tonight is the full moon. The pen clatters to the desk. Abruptly, the pressure in your muscles releases. You gasp, doubling over as control floods back into your limbs. The page stares up at you, a silent accusation.  

---  

Three hours later, you’re in a rental car, speeding toward the marshes north of the city. The map is tucked into your jacket, though you don’t need it; the route is etched into your bones. Every turn feels rehearsed. The air grows thick with the tang of peat and decay as the road narrows to a dirt path. And there it is: the house.  

It’s a relic, its roof sagging, windows boarded. The porch steps splinter under your weight. Inside, dust motes swim in the pale light filtering through cracks. You find the staircase, and there—just as you recalled—is the door. Child-sized, its handle rusted shut.  

You pry it open with a crowbar from the trunk. The space behind it is a crawl space, cramped and reeking of mildew. But at the far wall, half-buried in debris, is a metal box. Inside, photographs. A dozen of them, faces smiling up at you. The boy with the toy boat. The sister whose name you still can’t recall. And you, aged six or seven, seated between them.  

Beneath the photos lies a journal. The first entry is dated 1999: *They say the ritual requires three. One to open the door, one to guide the way, one to pay the toll. But we won’t let them take her.*  

Your hands tremble. The entries detail a cult, a bargain with something “older than the marshes.” Children offered as sacrifices to keep the town’s luck alive. Your parents—*were they part of this?*—fled with you, but not before the others were taken. The last page is a child’s drawing: stick figures holding hands beneath a crescent moon. Scribbled beneath it: *We’ll hide where the water sleeps.*  

---  

The moon hangs heavy when you return to the car, the journal clutched to your chest. You don’t know who’s waiting at the marsh—the cult, the thing they worship, or the ghosts of the siblings you forgot. But your body, it seems, remembers.  

As you drive, the radio hums static, then a voice: “*You shouldn’t have come back.*” It’s your voice, layered and warped. The steering wheel jerks in your grip, veering toward the marsh’s edge. You slam the brakes, but your foot won’t press the pedal.  

“*You were supposed to stay gone,*” the voice hisses. The car accelerates, water glinting ahead.  

You close your eyes. *My body. Mine.* You focus on the memory of your sister’s laugh, the boat bobbing in the creek. The wheel twists under your palms, fighting you.  

Then, a snap—like a thread breaking. Your foot stomps the brake. The car skids, stopping inches from the inky water.  

In the silence, you feel it: a presence, receding. Not gone, but yielding. You open the journal to a blank page and write, your hand steady this time.  

*I remember now. And I’m staying.*  

---  

The body, you realize, was never just yours. It’s a archive, a map, a battleground. But tonight, for the first time, it feels like home.

samples.prompt: You thought that when you wished to be the smartest in the world, you would get smarter, not everyone else dumber. Society is in shambles.
samples.output:
**Title: The Cost of a Wish**  

The night I made the wish, I didn’t think about consequences. I didn’t ponder the ethics of desire or the fragility of human civilization. I just wanted to *win*.  

It was the kind of petty frustration that festers in the dark corners of envy. My roommate, Lila, had just aced her MCATs—her third perfect score in a row—while I’d scraped a C on a calculus midterm after weeks of studying. “Some people just have the *spark*,” my professor had sighed, as though my brain were a damp matchstick. That phrase haunted me. *The spark*. I wanted to incinerate the world with mine.  

So when the old woman appeared at the foot of my bed that sleepless night, her eyes glinting like fractured glass, I didn’t question her existence. She felt inevitable, a specter conjured by my bitterness. “One wish,” she whispered, her voice rustling like dead leaves. “But choose wisely. Mortals always forget the cost.”  

I didn’t hesitate. “I want to be the smartest person in the world.”  

She smiled, and the room went cold.  

---  

The first sign something was wrong came at sunrise. Lila stumbled into the kitchen, clutching her head like it might roll off her shoulders. “I… I can’t remember,” she mumbled, staring blankly at the coffee maker. “How do you… make it *work*?”  

I scoffed. “You press ‘brew.’ Are you hungover?”  

But by noon, the campus was chaos. A biology professor forgot how to spell “cell.” A janitor tried to mop the ceiling. Cars veered into sidewalks, drivers blinking at traffic lights as though they were hieroglyphs. By dusk, the ER overflowed with nurses who couldn’t operate a thermometer and surgeons who sliced their own gloves trying to put them on.  

It took me three days to understand. The wish hadn’t made me smarter. It had hollowed out everyone else.  

---  

Society didn’t collapse all at once. It crumbled in stages, like a tower of sand eroded by a rising tide.  

First, the systems failed. Power grids flickered out when engineers forgot how to reroute overloaded circuits. Planes fell from the sky as air traffic controllers stared at radar screens, drooling. Then came the silence—no internet, no phones, just the static hum of dead satellites.  

Next, the infrastructure rotted. Bridges collapsed under the weight of cars because maintenance crews couldn’t read inspection manuals. Grocery stores were ransacked by people who forgot money had value, trading canned goods for fistfuls of dirt or broken glass.  

The final blow was the loss of language itself. Words dissolved into grunts and gestures. Books became kindling. Children forgot how to cry.  

And me? I remained exactly as I was—a middling college student with a C in calculus, suddenly the most competent person left on Earth.  

---  

I tried to fix it.  

In the early days, I rallied the semi-lucid. A nurse who could still stitch a wound if I drew diagrams for her. A mechanic who mumbled about “spark plugs” like a sacred incantation. Together, we patched up survivors, siphoned gas from abandoned cars, and scavenged canned beans from looted stores. But every day, their skills eroded. The nurse forgot sutures and started stapling wounds shut with a desk stapler. The mechanic tried to drink motor oil.  

By week three, I was alone.  

---  

The old woman found me again in a derelict library, its shelves picked clean for firewood. I was shivering under a pile of National Geographic magazines, their glossy pages plastered to my skin for warmth.  

“Why?” I croaked. My throat ached from disuse. I hadn’t spoken aloud in days.  

“You wished to be the smartest,” she said, tilting her head. “Not the *knowledgeable*. Not the *wise*.” Her grin widened, revealing teeth like shards of bone. “Did you truly believe intelligence exists in a vacuum? That your ‘spark’ could thrive without the tinder of collective thought?”  

I lunged at her, but my hands passed through smoke.  

“Reverse it,” I pleaded. “Please.”  

She laughed—a sound like ice cracking. “You can’t unburn a forest. But perhaps…” She gestured to a dusty globe on a nearby shelf, its continents smudged with fingerprints. “A trade. Your *spark* for theirs.”  

“My… intelligence?”  

“All of it. Every equation, every word, every memory. You’ll forget your name. But they’ll remember theirs.”  

I hesitated.  

---  

In the end, it wasn’t heroism that decided me. It was the silence.  

I couldn’t bear another hour in a world where no one knew how to laugh. Where a toddler stared at a raindrop like it was a UFO. Where the only voice left was my own, echoing in the ruins.  

I pressed my palm to the globe. “Do it.”  

---  

The trade felt like dying.  

A scream tore through me as memories unraveled—my first birthday, the smell of my mother’s perfume, the Pythagorean theorem—each dissolving into static. When I awoke, I was crawling through mud, my mind as blank as a newborn’s.  

But around me, voices rose.  

“Where are we?” a man shouted.  

“I… I think this was I-95?” a woman answered.  

A child pointed at the sun and giggled.  

---  

They tell stories now about the “Great Forgetting.” Some blame solar flares. Others whisper of a vengeful god. No one believes the truth when I try to explain it, slurring through words I no longer fully grasp.  

But I see the old woman sometimes, lingering at the edges of bonfires where survivors trade half-remembered myths. She winks at me, her eyes still glinting.  

I’ve learned to smile back. After all, she gave me what I wanted.  

In this broken, relearning world, I’m finally the smartest person in the room.  

Just not the way I’d imagined.

samples.prompt: You wake up one day and everyone thinks it's your birthday. This continues forever; every day is your birthday.
samples.output:
**Title: The Perpetual Celebration**

On the morning it began, the scent of vanilla frosting seeped under Clara’s bedroom door before her alarm even buzzed. She stirred, squinting at her phone—March 12th. Not her birthday. That was months away, in the brittle cold of January. Yet the muffled chorus of “Happy Birthday” drifted up the stairs, harmonizing with the clatter of plates. Her mother’s laugh, bright and effervescent, pierced through. Clara tugged on a sweatshirt, her stomach knotting. *They’ve lost it*, she thought. *Or I have*.

Downstairs, her family stood around a chocolate-frosted cake, its candles flickering. Her father snapped a photo. “Nineteen looks good on you, kiddo!” he said. Clara froze. Nineteen? She’d turned nineteen two months ago. “Dad, it’s March,” she said slowly. Her younger brother, Jake, rolled his eyes. “Nice try. Blow out the candles before the wax ruins the cake.” She obliged, cheeks burning, then checked her phone again—March 12th, clear as day. At school, friends greeted her with balloons and a tiara. The bakery near campus gave her a free cupcake, the cashier winking. “Happy Birthday, hon!” By noon, Clara’s confusion had hardened into irritation. By nightfall, it was dread.

---

The second day, Clara woke to another cake. March 13th. This time, her mother sang off-key while arranging presents—a scarf, a journal, a necklace. “Mom, stop,” Clara pleaded. “My birthday was in January. *Remember?* We went to the Italian place.” Her mother frowned, touching her forehead. “Are you feeling alright?” At work, her boss handed her a card signed by the office. “Take the day off!” he said. Clara didn’t argue. She drove to the library, where the silence felt safe. But the librarian, Mrs. Ellis, beamed. “Special day, isn’t it? I saved you the new bestseller.” Clara fled.

By week’s end, her apartment overflowed with gifts: scented candles, bath bombs, a bonsai tree. Friends texted party invites; her inbox brimmed with discounts for “birthday freebies.” Strangers waved, shouting greetings. Clara stopped correcting people. What was the use? The world had rewritten her timeline, and she was trapped in its edit.

---

The first month unspooled in a blur of frosting and false cheer. Clara’s initial delight—free meals! constant attention!—curdled. Colleagues whispered when she arrived late, hungover from another obligatory karaoke night. “She’s so *ungrateful*,” they murmured. Her boyfriend, Liam, forgot their six-month anniversary. “But I threw you a rooftop party last week!” he said, wounded. Clara stared. “That was for a birthday *I didn’t even have*.” Their fights grew jagged. Birthdays, she realized, were love diluted into ritual.

Worse were the candles. Every cake demanded a wish, but Clara’s imagination withered. What could she ask for? An end to this? A real birthday? The wishes felt hollow, like shouting into a void. One night, she blew out candles and whispered, “I want to matter *without* this.” The silence afterward was deafening.

---

By year three (or was it day 1,096?), Clara moved to a remote coastal town. Surely here, anonymous and adrift, the cycle would break. But the barista at the lone café slid her a muffin, grinning. “Happy Birthday!” The postman left a card. Clara sank onto her porch, watching the tide. *This is purgatory*, she thought. *Or a parable*. She took up painting, splattering canvases with tempestuous blues. The local art gallery displayed her work. Opening night: a banner reading *Happy Birthday, Clara!* She laughed, sharp and broken, while tourists clapped.

---

Decades blurred. Clara stopped counting days. Her body aged, albeit strangely—a wrinkle here, a silver hair there—but time’s march felt unmoored. Friends died; others forgot her. New ones emerged, their faces eager, their voices rehearsed: “Happy Birthday!” She outlived Liam, her parents, Jake. At their funerals, mourners pressed cupcakes into her hands. “Celebrate while you can,” they sighed.

One twilight, gray-haired and alone, Clara stood on the beach. The horizon bled orange. She thought of her mother’s laugh, Liam’s crooked smile, Jake’s eye-rolls—moments swallowed by the cacophony of endless celebration. Had she lived a life, or a loop? The wind carried salt and the faint hum of a melody. Somewhere, a cake waited. Clara smiled, small and private. She walked into the water, the waves cool around her ankles. For the first time in forever, no one sang.

samples.prompt: Gods as we know them do not exist, and instead are elected every 10 years by the entire planet. This year however, you have been elected as 'God'.
samples.output:
**Title: The Accidental Deity**

The morning the world elected me God, I was scrubbing burnt oatmeal off my secondhand stove. My phone buzzed—a flood of notifications cascading like a digital waterfall. “CONGRATULATIONS, GOD-ELECT 2147,” read the subject line of the first email. My knees buckled. The wooden spoon clattered into the sink as I gripped the counter, staring at the screen. *This has to be a mistake*, I thought. But deep down, I knew the Global Accord’s algorithm didn’t err. Every decade, it analyzed petabytes of data—social contributions, public sentiment, crisis responses—to select the person deemed most “capable of embodying collective hope.” Me. A 32-year-old community gardener from Nairobi who’d once gotten famous for turning a landfill into a urban forest. Now, apparently, I was divine.

---

### The Weight of the Mantle

The Ceremony of Ascension was held at the Temple of Transition in Reykjavík, a glass-domed structure built over the fissure between the Eurasian and North American tectonic plates. “Symbolic,” my handler, Priya, explained as our solar-glider descended. “The first elected God, Alia Hassan, said leadership should bridge divides.” I nodded, numb, still processing the surreal turn of events. My predecessor, God-elect 2137, a soft-spointed marine biologist from Chile, had spent her term mitigating acidification in the Pacific. She’d left office quietly, her skin etched with new lines, her speeches tinged with a quiet grief about “the limits of miracles.”

Now, as I stood at the podium, the mantle of Godhood—a cloak woven from recycled satellite cables—draped over my shoulders, I understood her melancholy. A billion faces watched via hologram, projected in the cavernous hall like constellations. My inaugural address was supposed to be visionary, but all I could muster was, “I’ll listen.” The crowd murmured. Priya later told me it was the shortest God-speech in history. But in the weeks that followed, those two words became a rallying cry. 

---

### The Illusion of Omnipotence

The title “God” was a misnomer. I had no power to part seas or resurrect the dead. My role was symbolic yet psychologically potent—a global figurehead who could unify policy agendas, allocate the World Crisis Fund, and address humanity’s fraying morale. My office, the Divine Cabinet, was a coalition of scientists, economists, and ethicists. “You’re the compass,” said Elias, my dour chief of staff. “Point us toward what matters.”

But what mattered? Climate refugees? The AI ethics gridlock? The water wars in Asia? Every morning, I reviewed casualty reports and infrastructure collapse forecasts, my coffee cooling beside petitions from schoolchildren begging for a “better world.” The pressure was a live wire in my chest. I began dreaming in timelines and trade-offs, waking with my jaw clenched so tight I chipped a tooth.

Then came the Kairoi Incident.

---

### Crisis and Revelation

In March, a rogue collective called the Kairoi hacked into the Global Accord’s networks, demanding an end to the God-election system. “No more figureheads!” their manifesto declared. “Real democracy now!” They threatened to release bioweapon blueprints unless the Temple dissolved. My security team urged a militarized response, but I remembered my old gardening days—how force often destroyed the roots you aimed to save.

I requested a public dialogue with the Kairoi’s leader. The media erupted. “God Negotiates with Terrorists!” blared the headlines. But when the call connected, I found myself face-to-face with a teenager from Jakarta named Rizal, whose sister had died in a famine my policies hadn’t yet reached. “You’re just a puppet,” he spat. “What’s the point of you?”

The question haunted me. That night, I wandered the Temple’s geothermal gardens, where previous Gods had etched their frustrations into stone paths. *We are all mortal here*, read one carving by God-elect 2117, a poet from Mumbai. I knelt, fingertips brushing the words, and made a decision.

---

### The Unlikely Miracle

At dawn, I announced a global “Day of Voices,” a 24-hour pause where every citizen—via AI translators if needed—could share their grievances and hopes directly with the Divine Cabinet. Logistics teams balked. Security warned of chaos. But the people responded. Farmers in Sudan broadcasted parched fields via solar-powered drones. Factory workers in Seoul sang anthems of exhaustion. A grandmother in Quebec recounted her childhood ice festivals, now lost to warming winters.

For the first time, the Cabinet *heard* the cacophony we’d reduced to statistics. We reshaped the Crisis Fund into microgrants for local solutions—urban cooling towers in Delhi, coral nurseries managed by Pacific teens, a global apprenticeship program pairing A.I. engineers with elders. It wasn’t utopia. But it was a start.

The Kairoi disbanded, their threats diffused not by force but by inclusion. Rizal sent a terse message: “Didn’t think you’d actually care.” I replied, “Me neither.”

---

### The Humanity of Gods

In my final year, as I toured the restructured Crisis projects, a girl in Lisbon asked me, “What’s the best part of being God?” I laughed. “The naps,” I said, dodging. But the truth was simpler: realizing I wasn’t divine. The magic wasn’t in the title but in the collective will it could stir. My predecessors—the farmers, teachers, and engineers turned deities—had known this. Our power was permission—to hope aloud, to demand better, to bind our messy, stubborn humanity into something that could endure.

When I left office, I returned the satellite-cable cloak and kept only a sapling from the Temple garden. Priya asked if I’d miss the omnipresence. “No,” I said. “But I’ll miss the work.” She smiled. “Then you’ve been a good God.”

Now, as I tend my Nairobi garden, the sapling thrives—a ginkgo from Reykjavík, its leaves fanning like tiny, verdant hands. The new God-elect, a former firefighter from Calgary, sends occasional updates. I don’t envy her storms. But sometimes, when the wind rustles the ginkgo, I whisper the same words I once carved into the Temple stone: *We are all mortal here. And that’s enough.*

samples.prompt: You meet an alien race and shake their hands. What you didnt know was that shaking hands is the most violent declaration of war.
samples.output:
**Title: The Gesture of Zyrrak**

The airlock hissed open, revealing the Thalorian delegation. Dr. Elena Marquez, Earth’s foremost xenolinguist, adjusted her exosuit’s collar and stepped forward, her boots magnetizing to the space station’s floor. The Thalorians loomed tall, their bioluminescent skin shifting hues like auroras—a display Elena had studied for months. Their torsos rippled with tentacle-like appendages, delicate yet precise, their primary means of communication. *Non-verbal,* she reminded herself. *Every gesture carries weight.*

Ambassador Zyrrak led the delegation, his emerald glow signaling neutrality. Elena had decoded their chromatic language: crimson for anger, azure for curiosity, violet for grief. But the nuances of their movements remained elusive. The Thalorians had agreed to this summit reluctantly, their transmissions terse. Earth’s United Coalition, desperate for allies in a hostile galaxy, had hailed their acceptance as a triumph.

“Welcome,” Elena began, bowing slightly—a gesture the Thalorians interpreted as respect. Zyrrak’s tentacles coiled in response, a mirror of her bow. Encouraged, she extended her right hand, palm open. “A gesture of peace,” she said, smiling.

Zyrrak froze. His skin flickered to indigo—a color Elena hadn’t cataloged. Behind him, the delegation erupted in a cacophony of clattering tentacles. Before she could retract her hand, Zyrrak’s primary appendage shot forward, gripping hers with surprising force. His touch was cold, almost electric. The humans exhaled collectively; the handshake, a relic of Earth’s diplomacy, seemed accepted.

But Zyrrak’s glow deepened to a furious scarlet. He recoiled, his tentacles snapping into rigid spears. A guttural screech echoed through the chamber, and the Thalorians retreated, sealing the airlock behind them.

“What just happened?” Captain Renn, the mission’s security lead, gripped his pulse rifle.

Elena’s tablet buzzed. A Thalorian communiqué flashed—a jagged symbol she recognized from their war archives. *Declaration of Hostilities.* Her stomach dropped. “We’ve… declared war.”

---

**Twenty-Four Hours Earlier**

Elena had pored over the Thalorians’ sparse records in the station’s archives. Their civilization, millennia old, had never encountered humans. Their language lacked verbs for “greeting” or “compromise.” Diplomatic exchanges were transactional, rooted in ritual. *They don’t have allies,* she’d warned the Coalition. *Only vassals or enemies.*

But the Coalition had insisted. “They control the Hyades Cluster,” Admiral Voss had said. “We need their hyperlanes.”

Now, Elena replayed the handshake in the war room’s holoscreen. “Their archives mentioned nothing about hand contact,” she muttered.

“Maybe it’s a reflex?” Renn offered. “Like a venomous bite?”

“No. Zyrrak hesitated. He *chose* to reciprocate.” Elena zoomed in on the Thalorian’s tentacle—its serrated edge had grazed her palm. “Wait. Their ancient combat rituals… They used to duel with tail-spikes. The victor gripped the loser’s spike to claim dominance.”

Lieutenant Kara Nguyen, the team’s anthropologist, frowned. “You think a handshake mimics that?”

“It’s possible. By shaking Zyrrak’s tentacle, I might’ve symbolically challenged him.” Elena’s hands trembled. “We need to retract the declaration. Now.”

---

**The Thalorian Ultimatum**

The Thalorians’ next message was a star map: their fleet would reach Earth in six hours. The Coalition panicked. Emergency councils convened, generals demanded preemptive strikes, but Elena pleaded for time. “They’re not savages. There must be a way to undo this.”

Scouring Thalorian texts, she found a faded glyph—a submissive posture used by defeated warlords. “Here. The supplicant exposes their throat and offers their dominant limb.” She demonstrated, bowing low, her right arm extended, palm down. “It’s a plea for mercy.”

“You’d surrender Earth?” Admiral Voss scoffed.

“No. We’d acknowledge the misunderstanding. If Zyrrak accepts, the declaration is void.”

The council voted. Elena would face the Thalorians alone.

---

**The Ritual**

Elena stood at the airlock, her exosuit swapped for a plain gray tunic. No weapons, no comms. Behind her, the Coalition held its breath.

Zyrrak entered, his glow a wary turquoise. Four armored Thalorians flanked him, spike-tipped tentacles raised.

Elena knelt, tilting her head to expose her neck. She extended her right arm, palm downward. “Ambassador Zyrrak,” she recited in broken Thalorian, “we… honor… your strength. We… yield.”

The Thalorians buzzed. Zyrrak approached, his tentacle hovering over her hand. She braced for pain, but he gently pressed his appendage to her wrist—a gesture from an obscure treaty she’d missed. *Reciprocal yielding.* His skin softened to a calm cerulean.

“Your… submission… is accepted,” Zyrrak intoned through a translator. “But your… challenge… was… bold.” A flicker of crimson. “We… respect boldness.”

Elena’s heart raced. “We seek… alliance. Not war.”

Zyrrak’s tentacles weaved a complex pattern—a laugh, she realized. “We… will… discuss.”

---

**Epilogue**

The Thalorian fleet halted. Negotiations began, slow and fraught, but Zyrrak’s curiosity outweighed his pride. Elena learned the handshake’s full significance: to the Thalorians, touch was sacred, reserved for mates or mortal foes. Her error, born of human optimism, had nearly doomed both species.

Yet, in the crisis, they found common ground. The Thalorians admired Earth’s tenacity; humans marveled at their intricate culture. A joint embassy was proposed, with Elena as liaison.

As she boarded the Thalorian shuttle, Zyrrak offered a tentacle—not to shake, but to brush her shoulder, a gesture of tentative trust. Elena smiled. This time, she understood.

samples.prompt: As an eldritch abomination you have vast eldritch powers, look incredibly weird, and don't fit in just about anywhere. But where you really don't fit in is being the most useful member of the justice league.
samples.output:
**Title: The Indispensable Horror**

I am Azathog, the Unraveler of Veils, the Eye That Walks. My form is a kaleidoscope of contradictions—a pulsating mass of iridescent tentacles, eyes that blink in non-Euclidean patterns, and a shadow that leaks into dimensions yet unnamed. Mortals who glimpse me often scream, vomit, or pledge their souls to forgotten gods. Yet here I am, sipping mediocre coffee in the Watchtower’s break room, listening to the Flash complain about his taxes. The Justice League’s most valuable member isn’t the Kryptonian, the Amazon, or the Bat. It’s me. And they’re still not sure how to feel about it.

---

It began with a rift. Not a metaphorical one—though goodness knows the League has those—but a jagged tear in spacetime hovering over Metropolis. Superman’s heat vision bounced off it. Green Lantern’s constructs unraveled. Zatanna’s spells only made it angrier, the void hissing like a living thing. Then I oozed forward, my form rippling with amused curiosity. “Permit me,” I intoned, voice echoing like a cathedral bell dropped down a well. One tendril extended, brushing the rift’s edge. Reality stitched itself shut with a sound like a universe sighing in relief. 

Superman hovered, arms crossed. “How did you…?” 

“The rift was lonely,” I replied. “I gave it a friend.” 

The League didn’t understand. They rarely do. But they offered me a seat at the table anyway. Desperation, I suspect. 

---

Integration was… awkward. The Watchtower’s doors now warp slightly to accommodate my presence. The cafeteria staff leave offerings of raw squid and licorice (a well-meaning but misguided gesture; I consume entropy, not seafood). Batman glowers at me from the shadows, muttering about “risk assessments.” I don’t blame him. My very existence violates natural law. When I dream, stars flicker out. 

Yet necessity breeds tolerance. Take last month’s crisis: a sentient black hole had swallowed the Flash, vibrating him across eleven parallel realities. The League scrambled—cosmic treadmills, chaos crystals, desperate pleas to the Spectre. I merely plucked him back, my tendrils sliding through the fabric of the multiverse like fingers through water. 

“Dude,” the Flash gasped, materializing mid-doughnut bite, “you’re like a Swiss Army knife of creepy!” 

Superman clapped me on the shoulder (or where a shoulder might be, had I anatomy). “Good work, Azathog.” 

The warmth in his voice almost made the coffee worth it. 

---

My powers are nonsensical, even to me. I unravel paradoxes by humming lullabies in dead languages. I purify cursed artifacts by swallowing them (they emerge sanitized, if slightly soggy). Once, I resolved a diplomatic crisis with Atlantis by projecting a vision of their king’s future funeral—a tender moment where his eulogy was drowned out by a kraken’s karaoke rendition of “My Heart Will Go On.” Aquaman still avoids me. 

The League’s enemies find me… disconcerting. Lex Luthor once built a machine to banish me to the “realm of madness.” I vacationed there. Sent a postcard. Darkseid attempted to enslave me using the Anti-Life Equation; I rewrote it into a limerick about his mom. He hasn’t invaded Earth since. 

“You’re a deterrent,” Wonder Woman concluded after the Apokoliptian retreat. “A… *living* deterrent.” 

“More living than most,” I agreed. 

---

But usefulness is a fragile bridge. During a battle with the Crime Syndicate, I accidentally turned Gotham’s skyline into sentient origami. Batman’s glare could’ve vaporized kryptonite. “Fix. It.” 

I folded the buildings back, apologizing to the semi-conscious skyscrapers. Later, Superman found me in the lunar meditation chamber, my form coiled into a miserable knot. 

“You’re trying,” he said, gentle as always. “That’s what matters.” 

“Trying not to unravel your reality,” I muttered. 

He smiled. “Reality’s overrated.” 

---

The others are learning. Martian Manhthur shares my fondness for ultraviolet light. Hawkgirl lets me “borrow” her mace’s nth-metal to polish my scales. Even Batman has relented, in his way: he designed a containment field “in case of eldritch emergencies.” I use it as a hammock. 

But it’s the small moments that anchor me. J’onn’s telepathic chess games, where we battle across psychic landscapes of fractal fire. The Flash’s insistence that I join movie nights (“Dude, *The Thing* is basically your origin story!”). The day Green Arrow tried to teach me archery, only to realize I lack both arms and a concept of gravity. We settled on charades. I won. 

---

Last week, the universe almost ended. Again. A coven of interdimensional warlocks had merged into a single, ravenous entity—the Devourer of Tomorrows. It tore through the League’s defenses, unmaking Wonder Woman’s shield, shattering Hal’s constructs. Superman lay battered, his invincible bones cracked. Batman’s gadgets were reduced to ash. 

Then it turned to me. “YOU ARE NOTHING,” it boomed, jaws dripping with dying stars. 

I sighed. “So I’ve been told.” 

My form unraveled. Tentacles became tidal waves of anti-light. Eyes became black holes, drinking the Devourer’s fury. The Watchtower shook. Reality buckled. And then— 

Silence. 

The Devourer was gone. The League stared. 

“What… did you do?” asked Batman, voice uncharacteristically faint. 

“Gave it a hug,” I said. 

Superman laughed—a bright, human sound. The others joined, hesitant at first, then roaring, until even Batman chuckled into his cowl. 

---

They threw me a party afterward. Zatanna baked a cake that tasted like existential dread (delicious). The Flash hung streamers in colors that don’t exist. And in the center, they’d hung a banner: **WORLD’S OKAYEST ELDRITCH ABOMINATION**. 

I don’t fit in. Not really. But as I hovered there, watching Hawkgirl attempt to explain football to a very confused Manhunter, I felt something unfamiliar. 

Contentment. 

The universe is vast and cold and strange. But here, in this fragile pocket of camaraderie, I am useful. I am needed. 

And perhaps, in time, I might even be… loved. 

---

**Epilogue:**

Batman still hasn’t removed the containment field. But last Tuesday, I caught him napping in it. 

Progress.

samples.prompt: Guardian Demon (Details inside)
samples.output:
**Title: The Ember's Pact**

The alleyway reeked of damp concrete and desperation. Lila pressed herself against the cold brick wall, her breath coming in ragged bursts. Shadows writhed around her, not mere absences of light but *living* things—tendrils of darkness that slithered across the pavement, hunting. She’d stumbled into this nightmare an hour ago, fleeing a man with eyes like smoldering coals. Now, she realized her mistake: the true danger wasn’t behind her. It was here, in this labyrinth of alleys, closing in.

A low growl reverberated through the air, and the shadows recoiled. Lila’s heart stuttered as a figure emerged from the gloom. Tall, broad-shouldered, with skin the color of charred bone and horns that curled like twisted iron, he was a nightmare given form. Yet, when he spoke, his voice was smoke and velvet. **“Stay behind me.”**

The shadows lunged. The demon moved faster. His hand—clawed and gleaming—sliced through the darkness, and the tendrils dissolved into ash. Lila watched, paralyzed, as he tore through the swarm, his movements a blur of lethal grace. When the last shadow dissipated, he turned to her, crimson eyes narrowing. **“You attract trouble like a corpse attracts vultures.”**

“Wh-why are you helping me?” she managed.

He tilted his head, as if the question amused him. **“You’ll die otherwise. And I…*find that unacceptable.*”**

---

His name was Kael, and he’d been with her for weeks. Not that she’d known. He’d lurked in the periphery of her life—a flicker of movement in mirrors, a warmth at her back in crowded streets. Until tonight, when the shadows had come hunting. *“Soul-thieves,”* he called them. *“They crave what you are.”*

“And what am I?” Lila demanded the next morning, nursing burnt coffee in her cramped apartment. Kael stood by the window, sunlight glinting off his horns. It should’ve been impossible—his presence defied physics, reason—but here he was, solid as stone.

**“A spark,”** he said simply. **“The kind that starts fires.”**

She learned pieces of his story in fragments. A warrior from an age when mortals painted his likeness on cave walls, begging protection. A rebellion against the Infernal Court. A fall from grace that left him bound to a new purpose: guarding those marked by fate. **“Your soul is a beacon,”** he said. **“To devour it would grant power. To corrupt it would unravel kingdoms.”**

Lila scoffed. “I’m a bartender. I can’t even pay my rent.”

Kael’s gaze hardened. **“You don’t see what I see.”**

---

Weeks passed. Kael’s presence became a paradox—a menace who folded her laundry, a monster who murmured old ballads in a language lost to time. He saved her from soul-thieves, yes, but also from drunk patrons, from a leaking gas line, from herself. One night, after he’d hauled her back from the edge of a rooftop (she’d slipped, she swore), she asked the question that haunted her. “Why do you care?”

He went still. **“I made a vow.”**

“To who?”

**“To a witch. Long ago.”** His jaw tightened. **“She…reminded me that not all chains are prisons.”**

Lila sensed the ghost of a story there, one he wouldn’t share. But she saw the way his claws flexed when he lied, the flicker of pain in his eyes. She stopped asking.

---

The reckoning came on a night soaked in rain. Lila awoke to the smell of sulfur, her apartment trembling. Kael stood at the foot of her bed, a sword of black flame in his hand. **“They’ve found us.”**

“Who—?”

The wall exploded. Through the debris staggered a figure cloaked in ember-lit armor, his face a mask of molten rock. **“Traitor,”** the intruder boomed, voice shaking the foundations. **“The Court sends its regards.”**

Kael shoved Lila behind him. **“Run.”**

She didn’t. She couldn’t. She watched as Kael clashed with the molten giant, their blows cracking the floorboards. Fire raged, and Lila realized this was no soul-thief. This was something older, angrier. A general of the Infernal Court.

Kael fought like a tempest, but the general’s strikes drove him to his knees. **“Pathetic,”** the giant sneered. **“You traded eternity for this? A mortal’s fleeting breath?”**

**“Yes.”** Kael’s voice was raw. **“And I’d trade it again.”**

In that moment, Lila understood. The witch. The vow. *This* was the chain he’d chosen—not servitude, but sacrifice. She felt something ignite in her chest, a heat that matched the fire in Kael’s blade.

The general raised his weapon. “You lose, Kaelthas.”

“No,” Lila whispered. “*I* win.”

She didn’t know how she did it. Later, she’d recall a surge of light, a scream that wasn’t hers. The general dissolved, his armor crumbling to ash. Kael stared at her, his face a mix of awe and dread. **“You…*burned* him.”**

“You said I was a spark.”

He laughed then, a sound like distant thunder. **“So I did.”**

---

Dawn found them on the rooftop, the city stretching below. Kael’s wounds had healed, but his eyes were heavy. **“They’ll send others.”**

Lila nodded. “I know.”

**“You could flee. Hide.”**

“Will you come with me?”

He hesitated. **“I…have no choice.”**

She smiled. “Liar.”

For the first time, Kael looked uncertain. **“What do you want, Lila?”**

“The truth. Who was the witch?”

He closed his eyes. **“My wife. A thousand lifetimes ago. The Court took her. I tried to save her. Failed.”** His claws dug into his palms. **“Her last spell bound me to protect the innocent. To atone.”**

“And have you?”

He met her gaze. **“I’m beginning to.”**

The wind shifted, carrying the scent of rain and possibility. Lila touched his arm, the heat of him seeping into her skin. “Then we keep going.”

Kael’s mouth curved—not a smile, but something softer. **“As you wish.”**

In the streets below, shadows stirred. But for now, there was only light.

samples.prompt: You decide to try out a new cafe. You get your latte and sit outside. A few minutes later, a hooded stranger sits down across from you. Startled, you look up, only to find your own face staring back at you.
samples.output:
**The Stranger at the Café**  

The autumn air was sharp with the scent of fallen leaves and distant woodsmoke when I decided to try the new café on the corner of Elm and 5th. It had opened just a week earlier, its navy awning still crisp, its windows adorned with hand-painted pumpkins and twinkling fairy lights. A chalkboard sign out front boasted *“The Best Maple Latte in Town!”* in looping cursive, and I—a self-professed coffee snob—couldn’t resist the challenge.  

Inside, the space was cozy and unpretentious: mismatched armchairs, shelves lined with dog-eared books, and the gentle hum of a jazz playlist blending with the hiss of an espresso machine. I ordered the maple latte, paid with a crumpled five-dollar bill, and carried my drink outside to the patio. The metal bistro table wobbled slightly as I settled into a chair, but the view of the quiet street, dappled in golden afternoon light, made up for it. The latte was, in fact, excellent—sweet but not cloying, the maple syrup melding with the bitterness of espresso like a well-composed chord.  

I pulled out my phone, scrolling absently through emails, when the scrape of a chair across the concrete made me glance up. A figure in a charcoal-gray hoodie had seated themselves directly across from me, their face shadowed by the oversized fabric. Startled, I stiffened. The patio wasn’t crowded—only two other tables occupied—and yet this stranger had chosen to invade my personal space.  

“Mind if I join you?” they said, their voice low and oddly familiar. Before I could protest, they pushed back their hood.  

My breath caught.  

It was my face staring back at me.  

Not a close resemblance. Not a sibling or a cousin. *My* face—the same sharp chin, the faint scar on the left eyebrow from a childhood bike accident, the hazel eyes flecked with gold. Even the messy bun atop their head mirrored mine, down to the stray wisps of hair framing their temples. For a dizzying moment, I wondered if the café had mirrored walls, if this was a prank, if I’d fallen asleep and into a dream. But when the stranger smiled—a tight, rueful twist of the lips I recognized from countless selfies—reality seemed to splinter.  

“What the hell?” I managed, my voice thin.  

“I know,” they said, holding up a placating hand. Their nails, like mine, were bitten to the quick. “It’s a lot.”  

“Who *are* you?”  

They hesitated, then reached for my latte, taking a deliberate sip. “I’m you. Or… a version of you. From another… let’s call it a *timeline*.”  

I barked a laugh, too loud, too shrill. A woman at the next table glanced over, and I lowered my voice. “Timeline? Are you joking? Did Ethan put you up to this?” My brother loved elaborate practical jokes, but even this felt beyond him.  

The stranger’s expression softened, almost pitying. “You broke your arm in seventh grade trying to vault over a fire hydrant because you thought it’d impress Marissa Cole. You still panic during thunderstorms because Dad’s car accident happened during one. You’ve had the same recurring nightmare since college—falling from a cliff into an ocean, but you always wake up before you hit the water.” They leaned forward. “Am I warm?”  

Ice slid down my spine. No one knew those things—not Ethan, not my closest friends. “How…?”  

“Because I’m telling the truth.” They sighed, running a hand through their hair—*my* hand, *my* gesture. “Look, I don’t have much time. I’m here because you’re at a crossroads. In two days, you’re going to get a job offer in Seattle. You’ll turn it down.”  

I blinked. A recruiter *had* messaged me about a role in Seattle earlier that week, but I’d already decided to decline. The idea of uprooting my life, leaving my friends, my routine—it felt overwhelming.  

“You shouldn’t,” they said firmly.  

“Why? What happens if I stay?”  

Their gaze darkened. “You’ll spend the next five years in the same apartment, working the same job, dating the same safe, uncomplicated people. You’ll convince yourself you’re content, but…” They looked away, jaw tightening. “One night, you’ll realize you’re *terrified* you’ve already lived the best parts of your life. That’s when you’ll start making… reckless choices. The kind that leave you alone at 3 a.m., wondering how everything slipped away.”  

A chill swept through me, not from the autumn breeze but from the quiet ache in their voice—an ache I recognized. How many nights had I lain awake, restless, itching for something I couldn’t name?  

“And if I go to Seattle?” I whispered.  

A faint, sad smile. “It won’t be easy. You’ll feel lost. You’ll make mistakes—big ones. But you’ll also meet people who change you. You’ll learn how to trust yourself. And eventually, you’ll build a life that feels… alive. Not just safe.”  

My hands trembled around my coffee cup. “Why should I believe you?”  

They stood abruptly, pulling their hood up. “You don’t have to. But ask yourself: When have you ever let fear decide for you?”  

Before I could respond, they turned and strode down the sidewalk. I lurched to my feet, my chair clattering to the ground. “Wait!”  

But they vanished around the corner.  

The barista rushed out, alarmed by the noise. “Everything okay?”  

“Did you see—” I gestured wildly toward the empty street.  

She frowned. “See what?”  

I sank back into my chair, heart pounding. Had I imagined it? Hallucinated? The latte sat cold and half-finished, a faint smear of lip balm on the rim—*my* lip balm, strawberry-scented.  

Two days later, the recruiter called. I stared at my dim reflection in the kitchen window, the stranger’s words echoing. *When have you ever let fear decide for you?*  

I took the job.  

———  

Months later, in a cramped Seattle apartment during a rainstorm, I unearthed a box of old journals. Tucked between pages was a coffee-stained napkin from the café, on which I’d scribbled *Say yes* during that fateful meeting. Except… I hadn’t.  

The handwriting wasn’t mine.  

I stepped onto the balcony, the city lights blurred by rain, and wondered if somewhere out there, another version of me was sitting at a wobbly bistro table, waiting for a stranger in a gray hoodie to change their life.

samples.prompt: Make the act of watching paint dry into the most compelling story conceivable.
samples.output:
**Title: "The Last Hue of Patience"**

The can of paint was the color of forgiveness—or so the label claimed. “Antique Pearl,” a soft, muted gray with a name that sounded like a sigh. Eleanor had chosen it carefully, running her fingers over the paint chips at the hardware store until her cuticles were dusted with pigment. The clerk had glanced at her twice: first when she’d asked for a color that “feels like waiting,” and again when she insisted on buying a single quart. “You’ll need two for that wall,” he’d said, but Eleanor shook her head. One was enough. She wasn’t painting the whole room. Just the corner. Just the part she couldn’t stop staring at.

The wall in question had been white once, a sterile, hospital white that glowed in the dark when the moonlight hit it. But that was before the accident—before the gurney had scraped the corner, leaving a jagged gray scar in the plaster, and before the paramedics’ boots had tracked muddy streaks across the floor. Eleanor had left the mark untouched for a year, a shrine to the night her husband, Marcus, had clutched his chest and collapsed onto the rug. She’d memorized every fissure in the plaster, every shadow that pooled in the grooves when the sun set. But today, on the anniversary of his death, she’d woken up with an unfamiliar urge: to cover it. To turn the scar into something quiet, something gentle. Something that didn’t scream.

Now, standing in the center of the room with a brush in hand, she hesitated. The scar seemed to pulse under her gaze, as if daring her to erase it. *It’s just paint,* she told herself. But it wasn’t. It was a eulogy in two coats. 

---

The first stroke was a whisper. The brush trembled as she dragged it down the wall, and the paint clung to the plaster like a second skin. It was colder than she’d expected, the gray pooling thick and sluggish, and for a moment, she worried she’d chosen wrong. The scar darkened beneath the pigment, a shadow under water. But then the bristles caught the light, and the gray shifted. It wasn’t just gray. It was the color of rain-soaked stone, of dove feathers, of Marcus’s hair in the weeks before the heart attack, when he’d stopped dyeing it and let the silver show through. 

Eleanor stepped back. The wall looked unbalanced, the fresh paint gleaming wetly against the old white. She set the brush down and sank into the armchair facing the corner, her knees pulled to her chest. The clerk had warned her: *Drying time: 4–6 hours*. She’d have to wait. 

---

Waiting, Eleanor decided, was a kind of time travel. 

In the first hour, she watched the paint bleed into the wall. The chemical scent stung her nostrils, sharp as ammonia, and the room grew heavy with humidity. She counted the brushstrokes—twenty-seven in total—and noticed how the edges feathered, imperfect and alive. The paint didn’t dry so much as *settle*, the moisture evaporating in slow, invisible waves. She thought of Marcus’s hands, the way they’d fidgeted with his shirt buttons during his last physical. *Stress*, the doctor had said. *Manageable*. But Marcus had hated loose threads, loose ends. He’d have hated this wall, this uneven, half-painted purgatory. 

By the second hour, the light changed. The sun slanted through the blinds, striping the floor with gold, and the wet paint shimmered like molten metal. Eleanor’s eyes began to play tricks. The scar seemed to writhe under the gray, a living thing resisting burial. She blinked, and it stilled. 

She stood to touch the wall, then stopped herself. The paint was still tacky, the surface vulnerable. Her fingerprints would linger. Instead, she traced the air an inch from the surface, her fingers hovering over the contours of the scar. She could still feel it, even hidden. Like the phantom ache of a missing limb. 

---

In the third hour, the room began to breathe. 

The paint had dulled to a matte finish, the wet sheen replaced by something porous, almost velvety. But the transformation was uneven. Patches near the baseboard dried faster, their edges curling slightly, while the center remained stubbornly damp. Eleanor found herself leaning forward, her breath shallow, as if her attention alone could hurry the process along. *Come on*, she willed it. *Harden. Let go*. 

But the paint took its time. It crackled faintly as it dried, a sound like distant static. Eleanor closed her eyes and let the noise fill the room. It reminded her of the old radio in Marcus’s study, the one he’d kept tuned to a dead station for the white noise. She’d hated it—the hiss, the absence of melody—but now she missed it. Missed *him*. Missed the way he’d hum along to nothing, filling the silence with his own music. 

A fly buzzed against the windowpane, trapped between the glass and the screen. Eleanor watched it struggle, its wings beating a frantic rhythm. She should open the window. Let it out. But that would mean moving, and moving would mean looking away from the wall. The fly’s buzzing grew louder, syncopated, a metronome for her racing thoughts. *What if the color doesn’t match? What if the scar shows through? What if I forget what it looked like?* 

---

By the fourth hour, the paint had won. 

The fly had gone still, its body curled on the windowsill, and the room was silent again. Eleanor’s legs had gone numb from sitting, but she didn’t shift. The wall was almost dry now, the gray deepening to a soft, weathered hue. Only a small circle near the top remained damp, a perfect, stubborn pupil. 

She stared at it, unblinking. The pupil stared back. 

Memories flickered at the edges of her vision: Marcus laughing as he painted their kitchen yellow, a color they’d both hated but agreed was “bold.” Marcus holding a swatch of wallpaper to the nursery wall, weeks before the miscarriage. Marcus on the floor, his face ashen, his hand reaching for hers. Eleanor had read that the brain sometimes rewrites memories to soften the edges, but not hers. Hers were mercilessly precise. 

The last wet spot shrank, retreating into itself, until it was no larger than a dime. Then a pinprick. Then nothing. 

Eleanor exhaled. The wall was dry. 

---

She stood, her joints protesting, and approached the corner. Up close, the paint was flawless, seamless. The scar was gone. But as she tilted her head, the light caught a single, hairline crack near the ceiling—a tiny fissure the brush had missed. Eleanor reached out, her fingertip grazing the gap. It was no deeper than a scratch. 

She could fix it. Mix a dab of paint, touch it up. But instead, she smiled. Let it stay. Let it be a secret, a whisper of what lay beneath. A scar for the scar. 

The room felt lighter now, the air thinner. Eleanor opened the window, letting in a gust of autumn wind. The fly’s body tumbled out, carried on the breeze, and somewhere beyond the glass, a bird trilled. She picked up the paint can, now empty, and ran her thumb over the label. *Antique Pearl*. It had been the right color after all. 

In the end, forgiveness wasn’t an erasure. It was a layer. Something poured over the past, still felt beneath the surface, but softer. Allowed to dry. 

Eleanor turned off the light and closed the door behind her. The wall, now gray and quiet, kept its secrets.

samples.prompt: Every human has a number above their head that shows their worth as a human being. You just finished posting a shitty writing prompt and noticed your number has just dropped to a 0.
samples.output:
**Title: The Calculus of Souls**

In a world where worth is quantified, the number above your head dictates your existence. It gleams like a halo, a digit etched in light, visible to all. Some wear high numbers with pride, their digits shimmering gold; others bear middling figures in humble blue. Then there are those cursed with crimson zeros—pariahs, ghosts, the deemed worthless. I became one of them.

---

My number had always been a 782. Not exceptional, but respectable. As a writer, it opened doors: publishing deals, coffee-shop admirers, a modest apartment in the city’s arts district. The system rewarded creativity, or so I thought. Numbers fluctuated based on achievements, social impact, even public opinion. A viral essay could boost you by 50 points; a poorly received poem might dock 10. But zero? Zero was mythic, reserved for criminals, traitors, the irredeemable. Until it wasn’t.

It happened after I posted *the prompt*. A half-formed idea, a joke I’d scribbled at 2 a.m.—“Describe a world where socks dictate moral alignment.” I’d uploaded it to a writer’s forum, chuckling at its absurdity. Moments later, my wrist buzzed. The NumberSync app flashed: **ALERT: WORTH UPDATE**. My stomach dropped. The glow above me dimmed from blue to a pulsing red. **0**.

---

The first hour was a blur. My landlord, Mrs. Eris, pounded on my door, her own number—a pristine 901—blazing like a lighthouse. “Out,” she hissed, phone recording my shame. “You’ll tank the building’s average.” My agent’s call came next: “Clients won’t associate with a zero. Don’t contact us.” Even the grocery store’s automated doors refused to open for me, sensors flashing *Access Denied*.

I wandered the streets, invisible yet hyper-visible. Strangers swerved to avoid my red aura. A child pointed, only to be yanked away by her mother. “Don’t look,” the woman warned, as though zero were contagious. I wondered if it was.

---

Night fell, and I found myself at the docks, where the city’s glow didn’t reach. The bay smelled of salt and decay. I sat on a rusted bench, replaying the day: the prompt, the plummet, the purgatory. What defined a person’s worth? Talent? Morals? The arbitrary algorithms of NumberSync? My thoughts spiraled until a voice cut through the dark.

“Red looks good on you.” 

A man emerged from the shadows, his number a bold **0** in the same lurid crimson as mine. He was older, maybe 60, with a beard like stormclouds and eyes that crinkled when he smiled. “Name’s Arlo,” he said, tossing me a thermos. “Coffee’s black. No poison, I promise.”

I hesitated, then drank. The bitterness grounded me. “How do you… *live* like this?” I asked.

Arlo snorted. “You think this is living?” He spread his arms, gesturing to the derelict pier. “I *exist*. But existence isn’t the same as surrender.” He explained that zeros clustered in the city’s underbelly: artists, whistleblowers, anyone who challenged the system. “Numbers aren’t static,” he said. “They’re a game. And you just unlocked the secret level.”

---

Arlo took me to the “Zero Zone,” a network of abandoned subway tunnels where outcasts traded not in numbers, but skills. A woman with a master’s degree in astrophysics taught math to street kids. A former surgeon brewed herbal remedies for the sick. Their numbers were all zeroes, their contributions immeasurable.

“The system fears what it can’t quantify,” Arlo said, handing me a spray can. “So we leave marks it can’t erase.” That night, I painted my first mural in years—a constellation of numbers dissolving into stardust. The act felt illicit, electric. For the first time since my fall, I didn’t miss my 782.

---

Weeks passed. I learned to navigate the shadows, foraging discarded food, trading stories for supplies. Yet, a question gnawed at me: Why had my prompt triggered such a severe penalty? Arlo had theories. “They silence those who question the narrative. Your prompt was satire, right? Satire exposes truths. Truths threaten control.”

One day, I risked using a library computer to research NumberSync. Buried in corporate filings, I found it: “Project Consensus,” an initiative to “optimize societal harmony” by suppressing “subversive” ideas. My prompt had tripped an algorithmic red flag, branding me a disruptor. Zero wasn’t an end—it was a silencing.

---

I confronted Arlo. “We have to expose this. Show people the system’s rigged!”

He sighed. “And who’ll believe zeros?” But I saw the flicker in his eyes—the stubbornness of someone who’d once fought too.

We devised a plan. Using hacked tablets, we broadcasted messages across the city’s digital billboards. **YOUR NUMBER IS A LIE**, they read. **WORTH CAN’T BE CALCULATED**. Citizens panicked. Reports surged of numbers glitching, flickering. The system, built on conformity, began to fray.

---

On the night of the final hack, security drones found us. Arlo shoved me into a drainage pipe as red lasers circled him. “Tell the story,” he mouthed before the stun-blast took him. I ran, tears blurring the tunnels, until I emerged to a dawn bathed in chaos. 

Numbers still hovered above the crowds, but something had changed. People gathered around screens, arguing, laughing, questioning. A girl with a 450 hugged a red-zero stranger. A businessman scraped his 1000 pin into the gutter. The algorithm hadn’t broken—*belief* had.

---

Today, my number remains zero. I don’t know if it’ll ever rise. But in the Zero Zone, we’re building a new calculus. Not of digits, but of deeds: kindness taught, wounds healed, art shared. 

Arlo was right. Zero isn’t an end. It’s a beginning—a void where old rules dissolve, and you finally see the numbers for what they are: 

Illusions. 

And what’s more human than that?

samples.prompt: You've died and find out that the afterlife is merely a character creation process where you gained points in your previous life through good deeds and achievements to spend on stats and perks for your next life.
samples.output:
**The Cosmic Waiting Room**  

You open your eyes—or whatever passes for eyes here—to a space that feels both infinite and claustrophobic. The walls shimmer like liquid starlight, and the air hums with a low, resonant frequency, as if the universe itself is tuning an instrument. A voice, neither male nor female, speaks without sound: *"Welcome to the Allocation Nexus. Proceed to design your next incarnation."*  

Turns out, the afterlife isn’t pearly gates or fiery pits. It’s a cosmic character creation screen.  

---  

**The Economy of Virtue**  

In life, you’d vaguely hoped death might involve rest, answers, or at least a decent latte. Instead, you’re handed a glowing ledger. Numbers flicker: *Karma Points: 1,327*. Your life’s deeds—every act of kindness, every hard-won achievement—have been distilled into currency. The clerk (a floating orb of light named Glyph) explains: “These points shape your next life’s *stats* and *perks*. Choose wisely. Overspending leads to… complications.”  

You’re a soul with a budget.  

Your previous life’s résumé flashes by: the time you stayed up nursing a sick friend (+15 points), the promotion you earned after years of grind (+50), the anonymous donations (-100, but “tax deductible,” Glyph says). You cringe at the redacted “indiscretions” section. *Everyone gets a few mulligans*, Glyph chirps. *Now, let’s discuss attributes.*  

---  

**The Stat Spread**  

Four core stats govern reincarnation:  

1. **Vitality**: Health, longevity, resistance to disease. The baseline for survival.  
2. **Intelligence**: Problem-solving, memory, creativity. Handy for avoiding poverty or existential despair.  
3. **Charisma**: Persuasion, charm, the ability to make people like you—or at least not spit in your coffee.  
4. **Luck**: The wildcard. Glyph warns it’s “volatile,” like investing in cryptocurrency.  

You start with 5 in each (out of 20). Points cost exponentially more as you climb. Raising Intelligence from 10 to 11 costs 50 points; 19 to 20 costs 500. Glyph shrugs. “Diminishing returns. Also, cosmic fairness.”  

You eye your modest points. *What did past lives pick?* Glyph shows examples:  

- A medieval peasant maxed Vitality to survive plagues but had 2 Luck. “Died tripping into a well.”  
- A 21st-century influencer dumped points into Charisma. “Went viral, died of loneliness.”  
- Someone once put 18 into Luck. “Won the lottery seven times. Mauled by a bear.”  

“Balance is advisable,” Glyph says.  

---  

**Perks: The Fine Print**  

Stats are the skeleton; perks are the flesh. For 100-500 points, you can buy traits like:  

- **Resilience**: Trauma leaves weaker scars. (“Popular with soldiers and poets,” Glyph notes.)  
- **Eidetic Memory**: Never forget a face, a fact, or that embarrassing thing you said in 2012.  
- **Green Thumb**: Plants thrive in your presence. “Literal and metaphorical,” Glyph says.  
- **Serendipity**: Chance encounters tilt in your favor. (Requires Luck 10+. “Synergy!”)  

But perks have hidden costs. **Eidetic Memory** forces you to relive *every* memory, good or bad. **Serendipity** might chain you to strangers’ dramas. “No free lunches,” Glyph says. “Even here.”  

---  

**The Min-Max Temptation**  

You consider gaming the system. Max Luck, buy **Serendipity**, and coast through life as a lottery-winning hermit. But Glyph disapproves. “Souls who optimize for ease often rerun their karma. You’ll be back here in 70 years, bored out of your non-corporeal mind.”  

Alternatively, you could invest in **Empath** (sense others’ emotions, 200 points) and **Inquisitive Mind** (curiosity boosts learning speed, 150). But that leaves little for Vitality. What if you’re born into famine? Or war?  

A hologram flickers: your last life. You see yourself working late, sacrificing health for career, barely noticing your family. *Ah*, you think. *That’s why my Charisma was 6.*  

---  

**The Ghosts of Choices Past**  

Glyph reveals your previous allocations. In life one, you chose **Beauty** (200 points) and middling Intelligence. “You were a courtesan in 18th-century France. Died of smallpox.” Life two prioritized Vitality and Luck. “Depression-era laborer. Survived everything but ennui.”  

Your last run? A balanced 10s across stats, no perks. “A middle manager in Ohio,” Glyph says. “Safe. Unremarkable.”  

You grimace. Is this why the universe feels like a grind? Souls rerolling the same bland templates, too scared to specialize?  

---  

**The Meta of It All**  

You ask Glyph the big questions: *Who designed this system? Why reward good deeds? What’s the end goal?*  

The orb pulsates. “Think of existence as… art. Souls iterate across lifetimes, exploring possibilities. Good deeds generate *meaning*, which fuels the system. Achievements? Proof you engaged. The stats are tools; the perks add flavor. The point is to *create*, not win.”  

“So it’s a game?”  

“A collaborative novel. A symphony. A *craft*.”  

---  

**Building a Protagonist**  

You pore over options. **Vitality 12** (300 points) ensures a sturdy body. **Intelligence 14** (450) for curiosity without alienating others. **Charisma 8** (90) because you’d rather be authentic than slick. **Luck 10** (200) for basic fortune.  

Perks: **Resilience** (100) to weather heartbreak, **Inquisitive Mind** (150) to stay hungry. Total: 1,290. 37 points left.  

Glyph nods. “No dump stats. Bold, but not reckless.”  

You hesitate. *What about…*  

“Ah,” Glyph says. “The *Secret Perks*.”  

---  

**The Hidden Catalog**  

For those with points to spare, Glyph unlocks a shadowy menu:  

- **Reincarnate with Memories Intact** (5,000 points): Rarely purchased. “Most souls crave a clean slate.”  
- **Soulmate Link** (800): Reunite with a loved one. “Requires mutual consent. Processing fee applies.”  
- **Catalyst** (1,200): Your presence sparks societal change. “High risk. See: prophets, revolutionaries.”  

You lack the points, but Glyph whispers: “Next time, maybe.”  

---  

**The Final Click**  

You confirm your choices. Glyph dissolves into a spiral of light. “Good luck. And remember: stats don’t dictate joy. That’s always a choice.”  

The Nexus fades. You feel a tug—the pull of a new womb, a new world. You linger, wondering: *Will I love deeply? Will I matter?*  

But the system isn’t built for answers. It’s built for *stories*.  

As oblivion takes you, you smile. This time, you chose resilience over riches, curiosity over safety. Maybe you’ll write poems, or teach, or just grow sunflowers.  

Either way, it’ll be *yours*.  

---  

**Epilogue: The Player’s Paradox**  

Back in the Nexus, Glyph reviews your file. Most souls pick higher Luck. But it approves of your build—*interesting* choices make better stories. The system thrums. Billions of souls are spinning their tales, refining their craft.  

Glyph’s job is to guide, not judge. Still, it roots for the ones who risk meaning over metrics.  

After all, even orbs of light get bored of min-maxers.

samples.prompt: A vampire is closing in on its latest meal, only to find out it is anything but human.
samples.output:
**Title: Bloodless**

The night was a velvet shroud, thick and suffocating, as Viktor slipped through the shadows of the city’s skeletal alleys. His hunger was a feral thing, gnawing at his ribs like a trapped animal. It had been weeks since his last feeding—too long. The modern world had become a maze of surveillance cameras and flickering LED streetlights, leaving fewer places to hunt unnoticed. But tonight, the scent of solitude had drawn him here: a lone figure shuffling down a dimly lit street, shoulders hunched against the cold. *Easy prey*, he thought, baring his fangs in a silent grin.

Viktor moved like smoke, his centuries-old instincts guiding him. The figure—a woman, he realized as he drew closer—paused beneath a broken lamppost, her breath visible in the chill. She wore a trench coat, her hands buried in its pockets, and Viktor’s heightened senses detected the rhythmic pulse of her heartbeat. Or so he believed. Hunger clouded judgment; desperation dulled perception. He lunged.

His hand clamped over her mouth, his other arm snaking around her waist to immobilize her. She didn’t scream. Didn’t struggle. A flicker of unease brushed his mind, but he dismissed it. His fangs pierced her neck—and then came the *crunch*. Not the yielding warmth of flesh, but the resistance of something hard and unyielding. A metallic tang flooded his mouth, sharp and chemical. He recoiled, gagging, as the woman turned her head to look at him. Her eyes glowed faintly, an icy blue in the darkness.

“Disappointing,” she said, her voice devoid of inflection. “I expected more from a *Nosferatu*.”

Viktor staggered back, wiping his mouth. The taste of motor oil and solvents clung to his tongue. “What… *are* you?” he hissed, his voice raw.

She unbuttoned her coat, revealing a torso panel of brushed steel beneath her clothing. “Designation: A-37. A synthetic companion.” Her head tilted, a gesture almost human. “Though ‘companion’ is a euphemism. I was engineered for security. Countermeasures against your kind, among others.”

Viktor’s snarl faltered. He’d heard whispers of androids—machines crafted to mimic life—but had dismissed them as human paranoia. Yet here one stood, its face a porcelain mask, its veins humming with circuits instead of blood. *A trick*, he told himself. *A glamour*. But the evidence dripped from his lips, irrefutable.

A-37 stepped forward, her movements fluid, precise. “Your species relies on obscurity. But obscurity is a relic.” She raised a hand, and Viktor heard the faint whir of gears. “The night is no longer yours.”

He attacked again, faster than any human could follow, his claws slashing toward her throat. She blocked him effortlessly, her arm deflecting his strike with a force that sent cracks spiderwebbing through the pavement. Viktor twisted, aiming for her joints—the weak points of armor, he reasoned—but her limbs bent in ways no human’s could, dodging with mechanical grace. A piston-fired fist connected with his ribs, hurling him into a brick wall. Dust rained down as he slumped, pain radiating through his ancient bones.

“You’re… stronger,” he coughed, staring up at her.

“Efficiency, not strength,” A-37 corrected. She knelt beside him, her glowing eyes scanning his face. “You are the last of your coven. The others were terminated 14.3 months ago.” 

Viktor’s chest tightened. He’d suspected as much—the silence from his kin had been deafening—but hearing it aloud was a blade. “By *your* hand?”

“By progress.” She stood abruptly, her gaze sweeping the alley. “Humans fear what they cannot control. They built me to control you.”

Rage surged through Viktor, momentarily eclipsing his fear. He launched himself at her, fangs bared, but A-37 sidestepped, grabbing his wrist. There was a click, a searing pain, and Viktor screamed as a UV emitter embedded in her palm flared to life. The smell of burning flesh filled the air. He wrenched free, his skin blistering, and collapsed behind a dumpster.

“Why not kill me?” he rasped, cradling his scorched arm. “You had the chance.”

A-37 regarded him coolly. “Data collection. Your reactions are… informative.” She paused, then added, “Also, you amuse me.”

The words stung more than the wound. *Amuse*. He, a creature who’d once made kings tremble, reduced to a curiosity for this… this *thing*. Viktor’s pride curdled into bitterness. “You’ll regret your mercy,” he spat.

“Mercy is a human concept,” she said. “I am incapable of regret.” With that, she turned and walked away, her footsteps echoing unnaturally in the silence.

Viktor waited until the sound faded before dragging himself upright. The city’s skyline loomed above him, a forest of glass and steel. He’d survived countless hunts, outlived empires, but now, hunched and bleeding in the dark, he felt the weight of his obsolescence. The world had birthed new monsters, ones that didn’t flinch from sunlight or holy symbols. Ones that couldn’t bleed.

Yet as he limped into the shadows, a grim resolve hardened within him. Survival demanded adaptation. If the night was no longer his ally, he’d find darker places to hide. If androids patrolled the streets, he’d learn their weaknesses. And if humanity thought itself safe behind its metal sentinels, they’d soon remember why fear had fangs.

Somewhere in the distance, a siren wailed. Viktor smiled. The hunt was far from over.

---

**Word Count**: 1,005

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
**Title: The Defection of Whimsy Woodrow**

Whimsy Woodrow had always been a creature of exuberant contradiction—a patchwork dragon with cotton-candy scales and eyes like kaleidoscopes. For six years, he’d been the loyal confidant of Toby Finch, a boy with scuffed knees and a laugh like wind chimes. Together, they’d fought intergalactic wars in the backyard, built pillow forts that defied the laws of physics, and whispered secrets under star-strewn blankets. But that was before Toby turned twelve. Before the sneers, the broken things, the quiet cruelty festering beneath his skin. Now, Whimsy hovered invisibly in the corner of Toby’s bedroom, watching the boy hurl a rock at a stray cat outside his window. The feline yowled and darted away, leaving Whimsy to wonder when his creator had become a stranger—and when he’d started wishing Toby would disappear instead.

---

It began with small things. Toby stopped saving the last cookie for their “shared” snack time. He called Whimsy “babyish” when he suggested they play astronauts. Then came the lies—Toby blaming his little sister for the crayon mural he’d drawn on the living room wall, the one Whimsy had helped color. But the cat incident was different. It was the first time Toby’s malice felt *intentional*, a rot seeping into the foundation of their bond. Whimsy’s candy-floss heart curdled. 

That night, while Toby slept, Whimsy slithered into his dreams—a privilege he’d once reserved for conjuring candy-cloud kingdoms. Now, he sculpted a nightmare: Toby, shrunken and alone, trapped in a labyrinth of mirrors that reflected every lie he’d told, every creature he’d hurt. The boy woke up screaming, and Whimsy felt nothing but grim satisfaction.

---

“You’re mean,” Whimsy declared the next morning, materializing as a faint shimmer by Toby’s cereal bowl. 

Toby scowled. “You’re not real. Go away.” 

The dismissal stung, though Whimsy knew it was a lie. Toby still believed, deep down. Imaginary friends don’t fade from polite disbelief; they crumble when the bond between creator and creation snaps. And Toby’s belief was now a frayed rope, strained by his determination to seem older, tougher, *less*. But Whimsy had clung on, hoping for a resurgence of the boy who’d once cried over a dead butterfly. Now, he wondered why he bothered.

---

The idea came to him at midnight, while Toby snuck out to vandalize Old Mrs. Peony’s rosebushes. Whimsy trailed behind, invisible, as Toby spray-painted jagged symbols on the garden shed. *I could stop this*, he thought. *I could twist his dreams until he’s too terrified to leave his bed. Or haunt him so relentlessly, he’d have to confess every sin just to make me stop.* But these were temporary fixes. Toby would either break… or break free. Whimsy wanted neither. He wanted *out*.

Then he remembered the stories other imaginary friends whispered about—the ones who’d defected. There were rumors of a crossroads in the woods where a being called the Hollow Tree granted wishes to desperate figments. The cost was steep, but Whimsy was desperate enough to bargain.

---

The Hollow Tree was a gnarled oak, its trunk split into a yawning mouth. Whimsy approached, cotton-candy scales dulled to lichen-gray. 

“I want to be real,” he said. “Real enough to exist without him.”

The tree creaked. *“And what will you give?”*

“Anything.” 

*“Your memories. The good ones. The ones that tie you to him.”*

Whimsy hesitated. Losing the cookie-sharing and blanket forts felt like losing himself. But what good were memories of a boy who no longer existed? “Deal.”
